commands.name: aci_find
commands.doc:
Search for ACIs.

    Returns a list of ACIs

    EXAMPLES:

     To find all ACIs that apply directly to members of the group ipausers:
       ipa aci-find --memberof=ipausers

     To find all ACIs that grant add access:
       ipa aci-find --permissions=add

    Note that the find command only looks for the given text in the set of
    ACIs, it does not evaluate the ACIs to see if something would apply.
    For example, searching on memberof=ipausers will find all ACIs that
    have ipausers as a memberof. There may be other ACIs that apply to
    members of that group indirectly.

params.name: criteria
params.doc: A string searched in all relevant object attributes

commands.name: idrange_add
commands.doc:
Add new ID range.

    To add a new ID range you always have to specify

        --base-id
        --range-size

    Additionally

        --rid-base
        --secondary-rid-base

    may be given for a new ID range for the local domain while

        --auto-private-groups

    may be given for a new ID range for a trusted AD domain and

        --rid-base
        --dom-sid

    must be given to add a new range for a trusted AD domain.

-------
WARNING:

DNA plugin in 389-ds will allocate IDs based on the ranges configured for the
local domain. Currently the DNA plugin *cannot* be reconfigured itself based
on the local ranges set via this family of commands.

Manual configuration change has to be done in the DNA plugin configuration for
the new local range. Specifically, The dnaNextRange attribute of 'cn=Posix
IDs,cn=Distributed Numeric Assignment Plugin,cn=plugins,cn=config' has to be
modified to match the new range.

-------

params.name: ipabaseid
params.label: First Posix ID of the range

params.name: ipaidrangesize
params.label: Number of IDs in the range

params.name: ipabaserid
params.label: First RID of the corresponding RID range

params.name: ipasecondarybaserid
params.label: First RID of the secondary RID range

params.name: ipanttrusteddomainsid
params.label: Domain SID of the trusted domain

params.name: iparangetype
params.label: Range type
params.doc: ID range type, one of allowed values

params.name: ipaautoprivategroups
params.label: Auto private groups
params.doc: Auto creation of private groups, one of allowed values

commands.name: idview_apply
commands.doc: Applies ID View to specified hosts or current members of specified hostgroups. If any other ID View is applied to the host, it is overridden.

params.name: host
params.doc: Hosts to apply the ID View to
params.label: hosts

params.name: hostgroup
params.doc: Hostgroups to whose hosts apply the ID View to. Please note that view is not applied automatically to any hosts added to the hostgroup after running the idview-apply command.
params.label: hostgroups

output.name: succeeded
output.doc: Hosts that this ID View was applied to.

output.name: failed
output.doc: Hosts or hostgroups that this ID View could not be applied to.

output.name: completed
output.doc: Number of hosts the ID View was applied to:

params.name: continue
params.doc: Continuous mode: Don't stop on errors.

params.name: criteria
params.doc: A string searched in all relevant object attributes

params.name: timelimit
params.label: Time Limit
params.doc: Time limit of search in seconds (0 is unlimited)

params.name: sizelimit
params.label: Size Limit
params.doc: Maximum number of entries returned (0 is unlimited)

params.name: all
params.doc: Retrieve and print all attributes from the server. Affects command output.

params.name: raw
params.doc: Print entries as stored on the server. Only affects output format.

params.name: pkey_only
params.label: Primary key only
params.doc: Results should contain primary key attribute only ("name")

output.name: truncated
output.doc: True if not all results were returned

commands.doc: Migrate users and groups from DS to IPA.

params.doc: LDAP URI of DS server to migrate from

params.label: Password
params.doc: bind password

params.name: usercontainer
params.label: User container
params.doc: DN of container for users in DS relative to base DN

params.name: groupcontainer
params.label: Group container
params.doc: DN of container for groups in DS relative to base DN

params.name: userobjectclass
params.label: User object class
params.doc: Objectclasses used to search for user entries in DS

params.name: groupobjectclass
params.label: Group object class
params.doc: Objectclasses used to search for group entries in DS

params.name: userignoreobjectclass
params.label: Ignore user object class
params.doc: Objectclasses to be ignored for user entries in DS

params.name: userignoreattribute
params.label: Ignore user attribute
params.doc: Attributes to be ignored for user entries in DS

params.name: groupignoreobjectclass
params.label: Ignore group object class
params.doc: Objectclasses to be ignored for group entries in DS

params.name: groupignoreattribute
params.label: Ignore group attribute
params.doc: Attributes to be ignored for group entries in DS

params.name: groupoverwritegid
params.label: Overwrite GID
params.doc: When migrating a group already existing in IPA domain overwrite the group GID and report as success

params.name: schema
params.label: LDAP schema
params.doc: The schema used on the LDAP server. Supported values are RFC2307 and RFC2307bis. The default is RFC2307bis

params.name: continue
params.label: Continue
params.doc: Continuous operation mode. Errors are reported but the process continues

params.name: basedn
params.label: Base DN
params.doc: Base DN on remote LDAP server

params.name: compat
params.label: Ignore compat plugin
params.doc: Allows migration despite the usage of compat plugin

params.name: cacertfile
params.label: CA certificate
params.doc: Load CA certificate of LDAP server from FILE

params.name: use_def_group
params.label: Add to default group
params.doc: Add migrated users without a group to a default group (default: true)

params.name: scope
params.label: Search scope
params.doc: LDAP search scope for users and groups: base, onelevel, or subtree. Defaults to onelevel

params.name: exclude_users
params.doc: users to exclude from migration

params.name: exclude_groups
params.doc: groups to exclude from migration

output.name: result
output.doc: Lists of objects migrated; categorized by type.

output.name: failed
output.doc: Lists of objects that could not be migrated; categorized by type.

output.name: enabled
output.doc: False if migration mode was disabled.

output.name: compat
output.doc: False if migration fails because the compatibility plug-in is enabled.

commands.name: realmdomains_mod
commands.doc:
Modify realm domains

    DNS check: When manually adding a domain to the list, a DNS check is
    performed by default. It ensures that the domain is associated with
    the IPA realm, by checking whether the domain has a _kerberos TXT record
    containing the IPA realm name. This check can be skipped by specifying
    --force option.

    Removal: when a realm domain which has a matching DNS zone managed by
    IPA is being removed, a corresponding _kerberos TXT record in the zone is
    removed automatically as well. Other records in the zone or the zone
    itself are not affected.

commands.name: topologysuffix_verify
commands.doc:
Verify replication topology for suffix.

Checks done:
  1. check if a topology is not disconnected. In other words if there are
     replication paths between all servers.
  2. check if servers don't have more than the recommended number of
     replication agreements

commands.name: trust_add
commands.doc:
Add new trust to use.

This command establishes trust relationship to another domain
which becomes 'trusted'. As result, users of the trusted domain
may access resources of this domain.

Only trusts to Active Directory domains are supported right now.

The command can be safely run multiple times against the same domain,
this will cause change to trust relationship credentials on both
sides.

Note that if the command was previously run with a specific range type,
or with automatic detection of the range type, and you want to configure a
different range type, you may need to delete first the ID range using
ipa idrange-del before retrying the command with the desired range type.

params.name: setattr
params.doc:
Set an attribute to a name/value pair. Format is attr=value.
For multi-valued attributes, the command replaces the values already present.

params.name: addattr
params.doc:
Add an attribute/value pair. Format is attr=value. The attribute
must be part of the schema.

params.name: trust_type
params.label: Trust type (ad for Active Directory, default)

params.name: realm_server
params.label: Domain controller for the Active Directory domain (optional)

params.name: base_id
params.label: First Posix ID of the range reserved for the trusted domain

params.name: range_size
params.label: Size of the ID range reserved for the trusted domain

params.name: range_type
params.label: Range type
params.doc: Type of trusted domain ID range, one of allowed values

params.name: bidirectional
params.label: Two-way trust
params.doc: Establish bi-directional trust. By default trust is inbound one-way only.

params.name: external
params.label: External trust
params.doc: Establish external trust to a domain in another forest. The trust is not transitive beyond the domain.

commands.name: user_status
commands.doc:
Lockout status of a user account

    An account may become locked if the password is entered incorrectly too
    many times within a specific time period as controlled by password
    policy. A locked account is a temporary condition and may be unlocked by
    an administrator.

    This connects to each IPA master and displays the lockout status on
    each one.

    To determine whether an account is locked on a given server you need
    to compare the number of failed logins and the time of the last failure.
    For an account to be locked it must exceed the maxfail failures within
    the failinterval duration as specified in the password policy associated
    with the user.

    The failed login counter is modified only when a user attempts a log in
    so it is possible that an account may appear locked but the last failed
    login attempt is older than the lockouttime of the password policy. This
    means that the user may attempt a login again.

commands.name: user_unlock
commands.doc:
Unlock a user account

    An account may become locked if the password is entered incorrectly too
    many times within a specific time period as controlled by password
    policy. A locked account is a temporary condition and may be unlocked by
    an administrator.

params.doc: Defines an allow list for Authentication Indicators. Use 'otp' to allow OTP-based 2FA authentications. Use 'radius' to allow RADIUS-based 2FA authentications. Use 'pkinit' to allow PKINIT-based 2FA authentications. Use 'hardened' to allow brute-force hardened password authentication by SPAKE or FAST. Use 'idp' to allow External Identity Provider authentications. With no indicator specified, all authentication mechanisms are allowed.
